newsitem.title: GREECE: Time bomb attack wrecks Greek politician's office.
newsitem.headline: Time bomb attack wrecks Greek politician's office.

text.p: A powerful time bomb explosion wrecked the office of a former Greek public order minister on Tuesday but there were no injuries, police said.
The bomb was left in a plastic bag at the entrance of the fifth floor office of Socialist parliamentary deputy Stelios Papathemelis near Syndagma Square in central Athens.
Greece's socialist government strongly condemned the attack.

"The terrorist attack against the office of parliamentary deputy Stelios Papathemelis is the work of bullying cowards trying to undermine democracy," government spokesman Dimitris Reppas said in a statement.
Two Athens newspapers said they had received phonecalls from unknown people saying they represented the Revolutionary Nucleus urban guerrilla group and warning the bomb would expode in minutes.
Police ordered the evacuation of the building. Fire engines rushed to the area and firefighters rescued an elderly woman trapped in the elevator due to a power cut after the blast.
Special anti-terrorist police units scoured the building for traces of the explosives used in the time bomb.
"We had received threats in the past," Antonis Naxakis, a friend of Papathemelis' who had been at the office shortly before the explosion, told Greek television.
Papathemelis, 59, who served as public order minister -- responsible for the Greek police -- from October 1993 to March 1995, was in the northern city of Salonika during the attack.
He told television his secretary had been warned by police and had seen the bomb outside the office door.
The Revolutionary Nucleus group has claimed responsibility in the past for several bomb attacks against cars owned by foreign diplomats and Greek businessmen.
Greece's leftist urban guerrillas often target Greek politicians and dignitaries in their bombing campaigns.
